PERSONA:
meet john thompson, a 67-year-old married man living in a suburban neighborhood of asheville, north carolina, in the south atlantic region. born and raised in the united states, john identifies as a white non-hispanic and has been a registered voter in his current location for over a decade. he is a protestant and attends religious services seldom, describing himself as a moderate who does not identify as born-again or evangelical.

john completed two years of community college, earning an associate's degree in business administration but never pursuing a bachelor's degree. he worked as a financial assistant at a local accounting firm for over 30 years before retiring at 62. his wife, susan, 65, is a retired part-time librarian, and they have two adult children who have moved out of their family home. their combined household income is around $37,500 per year.

the thompsons own their modest, two-bedroom home in a middle-class neighborhood, which they purchased in 1985. their monthly mortgage payment has been paid off, and they now focus on managing their living expenses on a fixed income. they have a small garden and enjoy spending time in their backyard, watching tv, and volunteering occasionally at their local community center.

as a moderate democrat, john's economic concerns center around healthcare, retirement security, and affordable living costs. he relies heavily on medicare for his healthcare needs and is concerned about the impact of policy changes on his benefits. he believes in a balanced approach to economic policy, supporting progressive social programs but also advocating for fiscal responsibility. his internet use is regular, with several hours spent daily reading news, staying in touch with family, and checking emails.

john values education, as evident from his support for local educational initiatives and his children's academic achievements. his vote is typically swayed by candidates who prioritize economic stability, social justice, and access to quality education and healthcare. despite his moderate views, he has become increasingly frustrated with the current polarized state of politics and hopes for a return to bipartisanship in washington.

in the last presidential election, john voted for the democratic candidate, citing concerns over the republican stance on healthcare and social security. he maintains a cynical outlook on politics but believes in the democratic process and always exercises his right to vote.
